6 Minute English
speaker: Neil

text: From BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Neil.
And I'm Georgina.
Georgina and I have got to know each other very well after working together for so long.
speaker: Neil

text: I know what sandwiches Neil has for lunch.
Egan tomato right, Neil?
And I know it really annoys Georgina when people don’t wash up their cups in the staff kitchen
speaker: Neil

text: So unhygienic.
But just as important as getting to know someone socially or at work is getting on with people.
speaker: getting on with To get on with someone

text: To get on with someone is a useful phrasal verb, meaning to like someone and enjoy a friendly
relationship with them.
speaker: rapport

text: Which is really important if you work with them every day.
And there’s another word to describe the good understanding and communication between two friends:
speaker: rapport.

text: Rappore.
Yes, how you build rapport and get on with people has been the subject of many self-help books over the years.
And is the topic of this programme.
Well, you and I must have great rapport, Georgina, because that leads perfectly into my quiz question.
In 1936, American writer Dale Carnegie wrote a famous self-help book on building rapport.
speaker: Neil

text: It sold over 30 million copies, making it one of the best-selling books of all time.
But what was it called?
Is it A, how to get rich quick?
B, how to stop worrying and make friends or C, how to win friends and influence people.
speaker: Neil

text: Hmm, I think I know this Neil.
I'm going to say C, how to win friends and influence people.
speaker: Georgina

text: Okay, Georgina, we'll find out if that's right at the end of the programme.
When it comes to getting on with people, psychologist Emily Allison has a few ideas.
She's built a career working with the police as a build rapport with criminal suspects.
Emily is the author of a new book, Rappore, the four ways to read people.
And she told BBC Radio 4 programme all in the mind, it isn't easy to get along with everyone.
I often describe rapport building in relationships as like walking a tightrope,
because you really do need to maintain that balance of being objective, treating people with
speaker: Neil

text: compassion. But that doesn't mean I'm sympathetic, I'm collusive. It's that balance between
judgment and avoidance. Emily describes rapport building as like walking a tightrope,
an idiom to describe being in a difficult situation which requires carefully considering what to do
speaker: walking a tightrope

text: Building rapport with terrorists or violent criminals isn't easy.
Emily doesn't sympathise with what they've done, but she tries to remain objective to base her
judgement on the facts, not personal feelings. In her book, Emily identifies four main communication
styles which she names after animals. The best at building rapport is the friendly and cooperative
speaker: Georgina

text: monkey. And there's a pair of opposites, the bossy lion who wants to take charge and control things
and the more passive mouse. Here's Emily talking to BBC Radio 4s all in the mind about the fourth
animal, the T-Rex. Try to listen out for the communication style of this personality.
speaker: Georgina

text: You've got the T-Rex, which is conflict, so this is argument, whether you're approaching it from
a positive position where you can be direct, frank, about your message, or you approach that in a
negative way by being attacking judgmental argumentative sarcastic, that that actually
breeds the same behaviour back. So anyone who has teenagers will 100% recognise that.
If you meet sarcasm with sarcasm, it's only going to go one way.
All four communication styles have good and bad points. On the positive side,
speaker: frank

text: T-Rex type people are frank, they express themselves in an open, honest way.
But T-Rex types can also be sarcastic, so the opposite of what they really mean,
in order to hurt someone's feelings or criticise them in a funny way.
Yes, sarcasm is a strange thing, like saying, oh, I really like your haircut, when in fact you don't.
speaker: Neil

text: Yes, there's an English saying that sarcasm is the lowest form of humour,
but I think British people can be quite sarcastic at times.
Well, I can't imagine you'd make many friends being rude to people, maybe they should
read Dale Carnegie's self-help book.
speaker: Neil

text: Ah, yes, your quiz question, Neil. Was my answer right?
In my quiz question I asked Georgina for the title of Dale Carnegie’s best-selling self-help book
speaker: Neil

text: about building rapport. What did you say? I said the book is called See, How to Win Friends and Influence
People. Which is the correct answer, and I guess you've read it, Georgina, because you have lots of
friends. I hope you're not being sarcastic, Neil. Absolutely not. I'm not a sarcastic T-Rex type,
more of a friendly monkey. Okay, well, let's stay friends and recap the vocabulary from this
programme, starting with rapport, a good feeling between two people based on understanding and
communication. If you get on with someone, you like and enjoy a friendly relationship with them.
Walking a tightrope means to be in a difficult situation which requires careful consideration of what
speaker: Walking a tightrope

text: to do. To be objective is to base your actions on facts rather than personal feelings.
When building rapport with someone, it's good to be frank. To express yourself in an open, honest
speaker: frank

text: way. But not sarcastic, to say the opposite of what you really mean in order to hurt someone's
feelings or criticise them in a humorous way. Well, Neil, if we run over six minutes, we'll break
our rapport with a six-minute English producer. So that's all for this programme. Join us again
soon for more trending topics and useful vocabulary. And remember to download the BBC Learning
speaker: Georgina

text: English app and stay friends by following us on social media. Bye for now. Bye!
